etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French retentif, -ive or medieval Latin retentivus, from retent- ‘held back’, from the verb retinere (see retain)

definitions: (of a person's memory) having the ability to remember facts and impressions easily

examples.text: he had a highly retentive memory and was an accomplished speaker

shortDefinitions: effective in retaining facts and impressions

definitions: (of a substance) able to absorb and hold moisture

examples.text: soil should be rich and moisture retentive

shortDefinitions: able to absorb and hold moisture

definitions: serving to keep something in place.
shortDefinitions: serving to keep something in place
